abstract.para: After navigating to the Logs page, &cockpit; shows system logs according to the default or previously selected view criteria. To change the logs view, you need to adjust the log filters as described further.

topic.para: You can filter the logs according to the following criteria:

listitem.para: Time. For details, refer to .
Priority. For details, refer to .
Identifier. You can filter logs for a particular service, daemon or process. Available identifiers are parsed from the logs currently displayed according to the set filters.
Free-form filters. For details, refer to .

note.title: The filter criteria are combined
note.para: Bear in mind that when changing any of the time, priority or identifier criteria, the other ones are still applied. For example, if you change the time criterion to Last 24 hours, the priority and identifier criteria remain the same.

section.title: Filtering according to time
section.para: To filter the logs according to a specific time, you can choose from the following values:

listitem.para: Displays logs for the current boot only. The Resume button enables continuous refreshing of currently displayed logs.
Displays logs relevant to the previous boot.
Displays logs that were recorded within the last 24 hours.
Displays logs that were recorded within the last 7 days.

section.title: Filtering according to priority
section.para: The standard syslog severity levels are used (sorted from most to least severe):

listitem.para: The system is unusable. This is a panic condition.
This log requires your immediate action.
Failures in primary systems. You should correct the problem immediately.
Not an urgent error but should be handled within a specific time.
Not an error but indicates that an error might occur if no action is taken.
Unusual events that are not errors. No immediate actions are required.
Normal operational messages that serve as a confirmation that the system is working properly.
These messages are used just to debug the system.

section.title: Logs filters
section.para: You can refine the logs view here according to the following criteria:

listitem.para: Logs for the specified date or newer will be displayed. You can specify the time in the following way:
using the absolute date in the format YYYY-MM-DD

using relative time by prefixing the value with - or + and specifying units. You can use the following units: seconds or s, minutes or min, hours or h, days or d, weeks or w, months or m, and years or y.
Logs for the specified date or older will be displayed. You can specify the time in the following way:
using the absolute date in the format YYYY-MM-DD

using relative time by prefixing the value with - or + and specifying units. You can use the following units: seconds or s, minutes or min, hours or h, days or d, weeks or w, months or m, and years or y.
Enter an integer: 0 means the current boot, -1 is for the previous boot, 1 for the first boot, 2 for the second, etc.
Specify a &systemd; unit for which you want to display logs. Use one of the formats:

Enter a string that you want to find in the log messages. You can also use PERL-compatible regular expressions. Alternatively, you can filter messages according to message log fields in the format FIELD=VALUE. For example, CODE_LINE=349 displays logs with this value.
